data.title: Wrong result in Node debug console
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- Local Node v.8.1.1 
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. The following Code:
var numberA = 10 / "zero";
console.log(numberA); 
2. Execute Node.js Debug - In debug console is the output: **undefined**
    But the correct answer is: **NaN**.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Extra indentation of def when prefixed with "private"
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.0
- OS Version: Manjaro KDE Gellivara

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a ruby file.
2. Ensure `autoIndent` is enabled.
3. Write some function with indentation (by example, inside a class), then try to write end keyword

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

![Imgur](https://i.imgur.com/wY66iNe.gif)

![Imgur](https://i.imgur.com/bVYcuZo.gif)

This happen by default in vscode, but other extensions like vscode-ruby and vscode-crystal-lang also have this issue:

- https://github.com/crystal-lang-tools/vscode-crystal-lang/issues/18
- https://github.com/rubyide/vscode-ruby/issues/203

data.title: Picking a process ID for attaching with the GDB debugger is not possible anymore
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: Windows 7 Enterprise 6.1 (Build 7601: Service Pack 1)

I use the following launch.json configuration:

{
  "version": "0.2.0",
  "configurations": [
    {
      "name": "(gdb) Attach",
      "type": "cppdbg",
      "request": "attach",
      "program": "C:/02_tools/00_executables/BT_RTSIM.exe",
      "args": [],
      "stopAtEntry": false,
      "processId": "${command.pickProcess}",
      "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
      "environment": [],
      "externalConsole": true,
      "MIMode": "gdb",
      "miDebuggerPath": "c:/MinGW/bin/gdb.exe",
      "setupCommands": [
          {
              "description": "Enable pretty-printing for gdb",
              "text": "-enable-pretty-printing",
              "ignoreFailures": true
          }
      ]
    }
  ]
}

With version 1.12.2 it works as expected and I can select the process for connecting with the Debugger.:
![2c9e2bf](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26296473/30162141-d8a7215e-93d3-11e7-822c-2b027a202261.PNG)

Since version 1.15.0 I get the following error message: 

![process_picker](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26296473/30162237-4d480208-93d4-11e7-9d25-69e6e0f261da.png)


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Improve git implementation

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
The current git integration in VSCode has a couple flaws (most notably #9475) and could be improved.

I think Atom does a really good job with its git integration and would suggest something similar.
The main benefits (in my opinion):

__Not side-by-side__  
If you select lines individually, you know exactly which lines will be staged, because line x does not exist twice.

__Buttons not hidden__  
If you want to stage a selection, you have to go through the drop-down in VSCode, which is one more step and takes a lot longer, even if this is a very common interaction.

__Selection of single lines__  
As noted in #9475, this is currently not possible. A click next to a line should select exactly the selected line and not expand to any other line.

__Hunks__  
Nice to quickly scan the code and commit code blocks.

Here is a screenshot of Atoms git integration:
![screen shot 2017-09-07 at 12 06 37](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6564077/30158936-36caf10a-93c7-11e7-9766-8203e9fc9de6.png)

data.title: fixed the terminal and find widget key presses
data.body:
This should fix #30994 and #33833.

This function was added in [this commit](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/commit/8ffd4d78fc8a741fad7d3d0e4e8b76824fe6ffed), which fixed an interaction with the Esc key when the terminal find widget was visible.

I tried multiple scenarios with the Ctrl+A, Ctrl+V, Esc keys (both in the terminal and editor, with the find widget opened or closed) and I don't think there are any regressions.

CC @Tyriar

data.title: Escaping \\ in snippet using \\\\ outputs only one backslash
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1, Commit 41abd2
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Insert the following code snippet to `latex.json` (which is where user's tex snippet goes)
Or by clicking `File` -> `Preferences`->`User Snippets` and search `tex`.
```
	"Input a multiline eqn": {
		"prefix": "eqnmultiline",
		"body": [
			"\\[",
			"\t\\begin{array}{lcl}",
			"\t\t ${1:foo} & = & ${2:foo} \\\\",
			"\t\t & = & ${3:foo} \\\\",
			"\t\t & = & ${4:foo} \\\\",
			"\t\\end{array}",
			"\\]",
			"$0"
		],
		"description": "Input a multiline eqn"
	}

```
2. In a demo.tex, type `eqnmultiline` which will insert a code snippet as follows:
```
   \[
        \begin{array}{lcl}
             foo & = & foo \
             & = & foo \
             & = & foo \
        \end{array}
    \]
```
And I'm expecting a `\\` at the end of the three foo lines, which I use `\\\\` to escape. But the result is one `\`  at each line. 
[Snippet Grammer](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/userdefinedsnippets#_grammar) says using `\` to escape `\`. So I'm wondering if this is a bug.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: 
**Correct** Sorry for not testing using suggested `code --disable-extensions` before because I missed that line in comment . Tried it today and after disabling extensions, I cannot insert tex snippets even through Command Palette. It tells me `there are no entries to pick from`

data.title: Configuration for disabled extensions generates warning in problems window

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
If I have an extension disabled in a workspace (only), any configuration settings in my User config generate a warning "Unknown configuration setting".

I understand why this is happening, but there should be a way to inhibit the warnings, otherwise it continuously obscures my build process warnings and errors.

It would be nice if contributions for a disabled extension could be processed to allow the warnings to be automatically ignored.

Alternatively, could an 'ignore warning' option be added to the context menu? This could store the ignored warning in the workspace settings.

data.title: Search & Replace: diff editor becomes weird after replacing all

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:

1. search for something
2. enter a replace text
3. open a diff editor for a change
4. click on replace all in the viewlet

=> the diff editor's right hand side becomes empty
=> click on another editor and then back, now both sides are empty

Should we just close the diff editor after replace all?

data.title: Feature Request: Max Git Commit Chars Setting
data.body: Add a config option to limit the number of chars in a git commit message title. For example, I could limit my commit messages to 50 chars. UI wouldn't let me type more than that and force me to move more detailed explanation to the commit body. A countdown of remaining chars (like when writing a tweet) would then be possible.

data.title: Feature Request: iOS 11/Android IDE
data.body:
So, with iOS 11 featuring a file system and with Android obviously offering a file system in the native OS, is there any consideration to bring this or a lighter more iOS friendly version of VS Code to iOS so there is a proper IDE on the tablet platform?

I understand there would be restrictions for what it could do, but it would really help those who cant afford the best machines and who only have iPads or Android Tablets be comfortable with tablet based programming.
I know apps like Buffer and Coda exist, built there is always room for improvement.

Is it a bug?Maybe can be improved.
<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: win10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. create a es6 class extend react component
2. try to type "component" and then the IntelliSense suggestions will pop.It will show react compoent lifecycle functions like "componentDidMount"
3. If you create a "constructor", and then you try to type "component", the IntelliSense suggestions didn't show any react compoent lifecycle functions.

![](https://i.imgur.com/l8gkdRJ.gif)
[https://i.imgur.com/l8gkdRJ.gif](url)

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
I alreay disabled all extensions.
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Feature Request: Add features of grouping multiple tasks in tasks.json and running them in sequence or parallel
data.body:
Consider the **Task** in vscode works in the sharp of some kind of shell, _e.g._ sh, node, npm, gulp, I just wonder the possibility of grouping tasks and executing them in sequence and in parrallel (with the configurations in **tasks.json**). 
Say, when we run the gulp task, we can also run the jslint and mocha at the same time. Similar features can be found in framework [**AVA**](https://github.com/avajs/ava)..

I think I should suggest a PR instead

data.title: 改进建议
data.body: 当终端没有焦点时，按下终端快捷键应该是获取焦点，而不是折叠

data.title: arrow key is replaced by number wrongly
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version:1.15.1
- OS Version:
Ubuntu 16.04.1 LTS 

Steps to Reproduce:

1.using shortcut key to delete a line(ctr+shift+k)
2.typing the arrow key will be replaced by number(eg: 'up' changing to '8','down' changing to '2', 'left' changing to '4', 'right' changing to '6')

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No
